hedline.hl1: Firebombs in London Halt Commuter Trains

block.p: For the second Monday in a row, small incendiary devices hidden on London commuter trains brought the capital's transportation network to a halt this morning, stranding tens of thousands of rushhour commuters and Christmas shoppers bound for the city.

Although the three bombs did very little damage and resulted in no injuries, London transportation officials ordered the entire 254-mile subway network shut for several hours while they searched trains and stations.

For the second Monday in a row, small incendiary devices hidden on London commuter trains brought the capital's transportation network to a halt this morning, stranding tens of thousands of rushhour commuters and Christmas shoppers bound for the city.

Although the three bombs did very little damage and resulted in no injuries, London transportation officials ordered the entire 254-mile subway network shut for several hours while they searched trains and stations.
A spokesman for Scotland Yard said the police suspected the bombs were the work of the Irish Republican Army, the outlawed paramilitary group that is opposed to British rule in Northern Ireland.

The firebomb attacks followed a weekend of sectarian killings in Northern Ireland. On Saturday and Sunday, five people were killed in four separate attacks, inflaming tensions in the troubled province, where a total of 94 people have been killed in sectarian violence this year, the worst toll since 1982.
Late today, the I.R.A. announced that it would observe a 72-hour cease-fire, beginning at midnight tonight, for the period of the Christmas holiday.
